top_comment.text: But don't progressives love North Korea?﻿
top_comment.author: John Meyers Howard

comments.text:
+threewiseman1

Yeah, well, I doubt we'll ever learn. Not when more than half the country 
believes that someone is a traitor for letting us know that our civil 
rights are being violated. Truly ridiculous.

Anyway, nice talking to you. One of the better conversations I've had on 
the internet. Cheers.
comments.author: John Meyers Howard

comments.text:
+John Meyers Howard Oh please understand I'm not trying to claim Jesus is 
the same as the Kims. The Kims are tyrants. Evil tyrants. No doubt about 
it. While Jesus could never be accused of anything of the sort. The worst 
criticism I would level at Jesus was that he was misguided. The 
similarities I mention are to do with North Korea's perception of the Kims. 
That is to say, they see them as gods in all but name.
For my part, I enjoy the discussion of philosophy, history and theology. 
And I see no point in only talking to people who agree with me because then 
my understanding of the subjects do not grow. And while I'm sure I could be 
accused of being pushy, I attempt to only be pushy toward the type of 
people you mention, (the xenophobes, the bigots, those who use their 
religion as an excuse to promote hatred).
But you obviously aren't that sort of person. And I'd like to think I'm 
'grown up' enough to accept that we have a difference of opinion regarding 
the 'grand' nature of the universe, and instead focus on the far 
more pertinent subject of human nature. And on that subject, I think we 
both recognise that power hungry tyrants have used the same techniques over 
and over again to control populations, whether in the guise of religion or 
politics. And like suckers, we fall for it every damn time. My question is, 
will we ever learn? Here's hoping.
comments.author: threewiseman1

comments.text:
Well Historians would probably find a lot of differences between Kim and 
Jesus, but whatever.

I can't agree with you more. Humanity always leans towards extremism rather 
than the moderate path. If you think about it; Christianity, Islam, 
Buddhism, socialism etc. were all ideologies created to eliminate human 
hatred and suffering. But even as a christian I will admit that 
Christianity (as with all of the above) largely failed. It brought some 
good things, but in a true Christian world there would be little value for 
money, because Christians should give to the poor, give to the neighbor and 
to expect nothing back, and to see everyone as equals. But most 
conservatives, with their obsession with materialism, interest and 
xenophobia, are complete opposites of this.

The reason I'm still religious is both practical and spiritual. I have 
great respect for conservative thoughts like traditional family and I 
believe that Christianity sanctions these ideas, hopefully for my children 
as well. As for the logical belief, I have argued with atheists about God 
in length, but do not anymore. I look at things philosophically, life, and 
in particular my existence, has always been grand and mysterious to me, 
scientific explanations just don't do it.

I don't classify people based on their religion or lack thereof. But 
atheists I have met, both online and in real life, push their beliefs on me 
the most, and seem least interested to hear mine. My Mormon, or even muslim 
friends, do not do that.
comments.author: John Meyers Howard

comments.text:
+John Meyers Howard
"Jesus is revered because he was, even by historical accounts, a very great 
person who only taught positive things."
I would say two things about that. 1) Your average North Korean would say 
the same thing about Kim Jong Un. One of his father's titles was "The Sun 
Shines Out His Arse", or some such nonsense.
And 2) While many of Jesus' teachings were good, (forgiveness, altruism, 
charity), these aspects weren't ground breaking. If these concepts were 
entirely foreign to the human race, we'd have killed each other off long 
before Jesus was born. Meanwhile, the core tenet of Christianity, vicarious 
redemption, I personally find to be morally repugnant. But to explain why 
would be side tracking, so I'll leave it unless you want me to elaborate.
"Well in that case, that is what atheist fundamentalism looks like - 
replacing god with a party, or some other source and object of wonder and 
admiration."
Sadly, I agree with you 100%. I am, in a sense, anti-theist, but I also 
recognise that theism, in-and-of-itself, is not the problem. It's the 
infuriating aspect of  human nature to group-think and idolatrise just 
about anything. And it is that aspect that has allowed North Korea to take 
the shape it has. It took root in all those communist countries you 
mentioned. It has, at least in part, kept the Middle-East in conflict for 
millennia. And, to your point, there is even an atheist group in America, 
called Atheism Plus, that behaves no differently to a cult (exclusion, 
demonization, idolatry) all the while believing it's the answer to all the 
world's problems.
For me, it's a catch 22 situation. As an individual, I can't affect or 
promote any change to the way humanity, as a whole, thinks, even on a small 
scale. But I immediately distrust any organisation that, even on the 
surface, holds the principles that I hold. Because I know people are sheep, 
and it will all turn to shit sooner rather than later.
In sum, I think we largely agree with one another.
"I haven't had a good experience with (atheists), but that's irrelevant."
I'm sorry to hear that. If there's one universal truth I adhere to, it's 
that most people are dicks.
Pleasure talking to you.
comments.author: threewiseman1

comments.text:
+threewiseman1
Jesus is revered because he was, even by historical accounts, a very great 
person who only taught positive things. Kim on the other hand embodies 
nationalism and patriotism. But whatever.

Well in that case, that is what atheist fundamentalism looks like - 
replacing god with a party, or some other source and object of wonder and 
admiration. I am not arguing that a theocracy is good, both are bad. 
Freedom of religion is great. But North Korea practices state atheism. You 
can't say that it's not just because it's not 'properly atheist' because 
the same could be said for a religious theocracy. A country like Iran, if 
it would properly practice the religion it adheres to, would guarantee 
freedom of religion like some early muslim empires did.

It appears to be a stupid cult from the outside. Living under those 
regimes, our opinion would be quite different. Some sort of ideology has 
and will replace replaced religion. Thats nature of humans. And most of 
them - capitalism, communism, fascism etc. have not been very good.

I really don't have a problem with atheists. I haven't had a good 
experience with them, but that's irrelevant. It's anti-theists who I have a 
problem with. Their propaganda that religion causes all our wars, 
suffering, authoritarianism etc. ignores China, the USSR, Cambodia and NK. 
These states show that atheist extremism is just as bad as religious 
extremism.
comments.author: John Meyers Howard

comments.text:
+John Meyers Howard
"The way they treat Kim Il-Sung is quite typical of a communist state. It's 
a cult of personality, surrounding their leaders with myths and legends,"
Exactly my point. It's cultish behaviour. They ascribe supernatural 
abilities and myths to, and worship the state leader. Just like any 
theistic religion. There is no discernible difference in the way North 
Koreans think of the Kims to the way Christians think of Jesus. Both are 
revered. Both are thought of as more than human. Both are thought of as 
infallible.
In all the countries you mention, the reverence for a god has merely been 
replaced with a reverence for "the Leader", or "the Government".
But I think you'll find that any atheist you'll encounter on Youtube, or in 
your home country, will 1) recognise the similarities I listed, and 
2) be just as opposed to them as any other crazy cult.
In sum, I'll grant that you can label North Korea as an atheist country by 
the strictest definition. But in practice, it is a theocracy. A necrotic 
theocrasy, actually. And secondly, if you think atheist groups and 
individuals in the west support or condone the kind of regime North Korea 
has, even in mere principle, then you don't understand us, not even 
remotely.
comments.author: threewiseman1

comments.text:
+threewiseman1
You can be atheist, but you can't dodge the fact that any country so far 
that has practiced state atheism has also committed mass murder, the best 
examples being Maoist China, Democratic Kampuchea and USSR under Stalin. 
State atheism is just as bad as theocracy.

And North Korea is state-atheist. The way they treat Kim Il-Sung is quite 
typical of a communist state. It's a cult of personality, surrounding their 
leaders with myths and legends, though NK takes it to the next level. 
Still, the truth is that they have eliminated traditional religion. It is 
probably necessary in a communist state - because if the people believe 
that they answer to a higher power than the party, then the parties grip 
over their lives becomes a lot more weak.
comments.author: John Meyers Howard

comments.text:
+John Meyers Howard If you think North Korea is an atheist state then I 
have a bridge to sell you. It's called Kim-Il Sung Bridge. Named for the 
current president of North Korea, who, for the past eighteen years, has 
been entirely dead. But that hasn't stopped him, apparently. I might be 
inclined to agree with you, to an extent, on your other points, but 
don't try and pull this shit. You can't point to authoritarian 
dictatorships and say, 'See? Atheism is bad!', when all they've done is 
replace God with the Glorious Leader. There is no practical difference.
comments.author: threewiseman1

top_comment.text:
North Korea is mostly undeveloped and unpolluted, truly beautiful.  North 
Korea also holds massive mineral resources and in general has great 
potential for economic development.  The incentives to gain control and 
open up the borders are numerous, the only question is which super-power 
will do it.
 Personally I think the U.S. should make full claim to North Korea, 
creating it into a permanent state.  While this would give citizenship to 
North Koreans, it would also provide an equal opportunity to Americans in 
existing states to relocate. This would give Americans a safe and long-term 
place to invest within Asia to prosper through trade and development.  Many 
may even choose to retire there or have hobby farms. It would also 
eventually be extremely effective for U.S.'s favorite export of propaganda, 
being an "Asian Hollywood" for exporting American culture through movies 
and online content.  Even in an unorganized way, simple having American 
teenagers interacting more with Asian teens would be very positive to U.S. 
interest. 
If the U.S. fails to act, obviously China will make full claim and this 
will eventually lead to some amount of conflict with South 
Korea/Japan/Taiwan.  The mineral wealth really needs to be used wisely and 
it would be a huge shame to see North Korea become polluted by badly 
regulated industry.  I'd much rather see a hyper-loop built between North 
and South Korea to encourage trade and progress in an environmentally 
responsible fashion. It would be ideal for Chinese citizens to visit as 
welcome guest, rather than to take control over Korea's future. ﻿
top_comment.author: differentyesterday

comments.text:
+Tiktaalic The main difference in this instance is that beyond the 
minerals, the location is a resource in and of itself.  That's a resource 
you can't exploit remotely and thus are forced to take over in a visible 
fashion. Not just Americans, but many citizens would think twice of 
relocating to Asia, especially to run a business.  Yet those same 
individuals are much more likely to make the leap to invest if they have 
the assurance of the American legal system, including copyright laws.  The 
U.S. if viewed as being comprised of various entities with self interest 
within the corporate/banking system, would desire to tax and 
monitor/manipulate those businesses and individuals. Instead of being lost 
to the opportunities within China, the U.S. could hold the reigns of some 
of the new innovators in the technological race without having to invest 
directly. 
I totally agree that South Korea is amazing and can be learned from, and 
that is why I feel wealthy individuals would want full access through North 
Korea.  A lot of progress could be made in a short period of time.  The 
technology could then be exported in small doses to mainland U.S. consumers 
now and other growing markets later. Japan's many problems as of recent 
only highlights the extreme need of the West to actively engage in 
facilitating technological innovations.  Progress has been slowed down in 
relation to Fukushima. While this all sounds ridiculous, drastic measures 
do need to take place to get where we all want to be as a society.  While 
it is true that this proposal doesn't fit the normal model the U.S. has 
taken in the past, the model is changing due to limitations on accessible 
resources.  It's going to make a lot more sense to move the people, than to 
move the things to the people.
comments.author: differentyesterday

comments.text:
+Nate Fisher India's people were "subjects", not British citizens with full 
and equal rights, including the right to move to Britain. While some states 
have tried to succeed from the U.S such as Hawaii, even minor changes to 
private property ownership have been limited.  There are clear and tangible 
benefits to the residents of Hawaii, and realistically their sovereignty 
would only be quickly endangered by another country, perhaps even by an 
ally of America. For instance Japan loves Hawaii, and if the U.S. discarded 
Hawaii then Japan may hug a little too tightly. 
The U.S. State of North Korea would be a relatively long term endeavor for 
full realization of improved economies, but likely not more than 1 
generation.  Much like the progress of Virgin Galactic, it would be a 
project involving corporate investment to expedite the mutual progress of 
citizens in many countries.  Even if North Korea's future generation did 
decide to rebel, the return on profit and the benefits to Americans in 
general would have already been returned many times over.  The U.S. already 
has and will continue to spend greatly to provide military presence in and 
around Korea.  It would be best for the U.S. to create some amount of 
permanency in Asia now while it still has military power.  U.S. military 
advantage is fading quickly, and even in 10 years it likely won't be nearly 
as cut and dry; time is of the essence.

oblivion, just to deny us their land.  So, in the end, we would start a 
world war, causing millions of deaths, mostly innocent civilians, lose our 
reputation with the international community, and for what?  The NKs will 
reduce their own country to a pile of radioactive slag, rendering it 
useless to everyone.  The potential gains are small compared to the 
possible consequences, so your plan would never work.
comments.author: piccolo11394

comments.text:
+piccolo11394 In 2012, the U.S. spent 691.2 billion on military.  That's 
40% of the entire world's military budget.  In comparison China spent 381.5 
billion which is 22%.  Not that the U.S. would need it, but it could also 
expect some assistance from the UK and Japan, which combined outweigh 
Russia's 2012 expenditures. If the U.S. desired North Korea, it could have 
it without use of any actual humans on the ground. There would be a lot of 
posturing of course, but literally any country would surrender quickly if 
the U.S. was willing to use it's military power instead of attempt 
diplomacy or install puppet leaders. The technological investments in 
remote weaponry have been vast and are extremely effective if actually 
utilized.
comments.author: differentyesterday

comments.text:

into account a lot of factors that would make that impossible.  First, you 
would have to get rid of all of the leadership, and the Nukes they have 
access to, not to mention the fanatically loyal military that would never 
accept American rule.  Then there's China, who would NEVER let the U.S. 
take control of North Korea, one of their closest allies.  They would 
almost certainly try to start a war, and how would we be able to fight 
China, when North Korea is right in their back yard?  It would just be a 
repeat of the Korean War, but much bloodier.
comments.author: piccolo11394

comments.text:

Korea.  North Koreans not only would be able to visit South Korea, but 
anywhere else in the world, just like any other American.  Many may decide 
to move to South Korea but hold dual U.S. citizenship.
 The U.S. overseeing a private company installing a hyper-loop (rapid 
public transit) would be an example of even hastening interaction between 
the now opened border dividing Korea.  
There would be nothing immoral about the U.S. increasing it's relationship 
with Korea.  Yes, half the country would become a U.S. State.  Yet in 
reality all that really means is that carefully regulated ecological 
investments would occur rapidly. Many investors would feel comfortable 
within the familiarity of the U.S. legal system.  A U.S. state within Asia 
would be a huge boom to both economies and rapidly speed up progress in 
technology and human rights. China ironically would greatly benefit, as 
there would be strong trade between this new U.S. state and China.  It also 
would not discourage Chinese investment and cooperation, just like in any 
other U.S. State.  
As you must already be aware, I believe there is historical and logical 
facts indicating China would never allow what you describe as 
"reunification" within Korea. If the U.S. military must protect both South 
Korea and Japan, which both countries obviously actively have sought out, 
perhaps it makes more economic sense to create a U.S. state within Korea.
